column1: Essex County is a county in the northeastern part of the U.S. state of Massachusetts. As of the 2010 census
column4: making it the third-most populous county in the state. It is part of the Greater Boston area (the Boston–Cambridge–Newton
column5: MA–NH Metropolitan Statistical Area). The largest city in Essex County is Lynn. The county was named after the English county of Essex.

column1: It has two traditional county seats: Salem and Lawrence. Prior to the dissolution of the county government in 1999
column2: Salem had jurisdiction over the Southern Essex District
column3: and Lawrence had jurisdiction over the Northern Essex District
column4: but currently these cities do not function as seats of government. However
column5: the county and the districts remain as administrative regions recognized by various governmental agencies
column6: which gathered vital statistics or disposed of judicial case loads under these geographic subdivisions
column7: and are required to keep the records based on them. The county has been designated the Essex National Heritage Area by the National Park Service.

column1: The county was created by the General Court of the Massachusetts Bay Colony on May 10
column3: when it was ordered "that the whole plantation within this jurisdiction be divided into four sheires". Named after the county in England
column4: Essex then comprised the towns of Salem
column13: both located north of the Merrimack River
column14: were annexed to Essex County. These communities had been part of Massachusetts' colonial-era Norfolk County. The remaining four towns within colonial Norfolk County
column15: which included Exeter and what is now Portsmouth
column16: were transferred to what became Rockingham County in the Province of New Hampshire. The ten large founding Massachusetts-based settlements were then subdivided over the centuries to produce Essex County's modern composition of cities and towns.

column1: Essex County is where Elbridge Gerry (who was born and raised in Marblehead) created a legislative district in 1812 that gave rise to the word gerrymandering.
Due to a confluence of floods
column3: and severe winter storms
column4: Essex County has had more disaster declarations than most other U.S. counties

column1: From the founding of the Republican Party until the New Deal
column2: Essex County was a Republican stronghold in presidential elections. Since 1936
column3: it has trended Democratic
column4: with Dwight Eisenhower in 1952 and 1956 and Ronald Reagan in 1980 and 1984 being the only Republicans to carry the county since.

column2: Essex County exists today only as a historical geographic region
column3: and has no county government. All former county functions were assumed by state agencies in 1999. The sheriff (currently Kevin Coppinger) and some other regional officials with specific duties are still elected locally to perform duties within the county region
column4: but there is no county council
column6: or county employees. Communities are now granted the right to form their own regional compacts for sharing services. See also: League of Women Voters page on Massachusetts counties.

column1: Essex County is roughly diamond-shaped and occupies the northeastern corner of the state of Massachusetts.
According to the U.S. Census Bureau
column2: the county has a total area of 828 square miles (2
column5: 280 km2) is land and 336 square miles (870 km2) (41%) is water. Essex County is adjacent to Rockingham County
column7: the Atlantic Ocean (specifically the Gulf of Maine and Massachusetts Bay) to the east
column9: Middlesex County to the west and a very small portion of Hillsborough County
column10: New Hampshire to the far north west in Methuen. All county land is incorporated into towns or cities.

column1: Essex County includes the North Shore
column3: and the lower portions of the Merrimack Valley.

column1: The MBTA commuter rail has two lines operating in Essex County: the Haverhill Line and the Newburyport Line
column2: both of which go toward Boston. Close to Boston
column3: MBTA buses also exist. The MVRTA is a bus company that connects cities within the Merrimack Valley portion of Essex County.

Essex National Heritage Area (ENHA) was authorized by Congress. The heritage area consists of all of Essex County
column5: 300 km2) area between the Atlantic Coast and the Merrimack Valley. The area includes 34 cities and towns; two National Historic Sites (Salem Maritime National Historic Site and Saugus Iron Works National Historic Site); and thousands of historic sites and districts that illuminate colonial settlement
column6: the development of the shoe and textile industries
column7: and the growth and decline of the maritime industries
column10: and the China trade. The Essex National Heritage Area is one of 49 heritage areas designated by Congress
column11: affiliated with the National Park Service.

column1: The Essex National Heritage Commission is a non-profit organization chartered to promote tourism and cultural awareness of the area
column2: connecting people to the places of Essex County
column3: MA. The Commission's mission is to promote and preserve the historic
column4: cultural and natural resources of the ENHA by rallying community support around saving the character of the area. This is accomplished through the commission's projects and programs
column8: and the annual September weekend event Trails & Sails
column9: as well as other important regional partnership building projects like the Essex Heritage Scenic Byway
column10: and the Border to Boston trail.
